prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user wants to know if the author is in the wrong for wanting their girlfriend to start paying some bills after a single incident. 

First, I need to understand the situation. The couple lives together. The man pays all the bills because he works full-time, and the girlfriend works part-time. The issue arose when he asked her to pay for takeout that cost under $40 because he forgot his wallet. Her reaction was negative, and now he's considering making her contribute more to the bills, even though she can't pay a lot.

So, is the author wrong? Let's break it down. The main points here are financial responsibility, communication, and fairness. The man has been covering all expenses, which might be a point of contention. The girlfriend's reaction to paying for takeout could indicate underlying issues about financial contributions. 

But the key here is that the author is reacting to a single incident. Making someone start paying bills because of one event might not be fair. Maybe there's a bigger issue about expectations in the relationship. Did they ever discuss financial responsibilities? If the author never brought it up before, expecting her to just start now could be abrupt.

Also, considering their income levels: the man earns more, so he might be okay shouldering more expenses. However, the girlfriend's part-time job might mean she can contribute a bit, even if it's not a lot. The author's frustration could stem from feeling taken advantage of, but is one instance enough to justify changing the financial arrangement?

Another angle is communication. The author says he's been unable to get the incident out of his head. Maybe this is a sign that he needs to talk to her about his feelings instead of making unilateral decisions. Jumping to making her pay bills after one argument might be disproportionate. 

On the other hand, the author might feel that fairness requires some contribution from both sides. However, the approach of using a single incident to demand a change in financial responsibility could be seen as unfair. The girlfriend's reaction might be due to stress or other factors, but the author is generalizing from one event.

I should also consider cultural or societal norms. In some relationships, one partner might handle all the bills if their income allows, especially if the other has a lower income. The problem here is the sudden shift triggered by a minor incident. 

So, putting it all together, the author might be in the wrong because he's overreacting to a single event and not considering the broader context of their relationship dynamics and financial discussions. It seems like there's a lack of communication about expectations, and making a significant change based on one incident isn't fair. The answer would likely be A (the author is in the wrong) because the approach is disproportionate and lacks prior discussion.
